abstract: pmc Prev Med Rep 2904 pmedr Preventive Medicine Reports 2211-3355 Elsevier PMC12491731 PMC12491731.1 12491731 12491731 10.1016/j.pmedr.2025.103205 S2211-3355(25)00244-X 103205 1 Regular article Participation, knowledge, and attitudes toward cervical cancer screening among migrant Burmese women on China-Myanmar border: a cross-sectional study Hu Jiawei a b 1 Wang Honghao a 1 Zhao Shuang c Huang Liuye d Chen Xiaoqing e Zhao Xuelian a Zhang Yong zhangyong@cicams.ac.cn a ⁎ Zhao Fanghui zhaofangh@cicams.ac.cn a ⁎ a b c d e ⁎ zhangyong@cicams.ac.cn zhaofangh@cicams.ac.cn 1 These authors have contributed equally to this work and share first authorship. 10 2025 18 8 2025 58 495729 103205 10 5 2025 6 8 2025 7 8 2025 18 08 2025 04 10 2025 04 10 2025 © 2025 The Authors 2025 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/). Objective This study aimed to investigate cervical cancer screening participation, knowledge of cervical cancer and screening, attitudes toward relevant healthcare services, and associated factors among migrant Burmese women in Mangshi, a county on the China-Myanmar border in Southwest China's Yunnan province. Methods A cross-sectional study was conducted in Mangshi Maternal and Child Health Hospital from October 2020 to December 2021. Migrant Burmese women attending routine gynecological examinations were recruited via convenient sampling. An interviewer-administered questionnaire was utilized to collect data. Logistic regressions were utilized to assess factors associated with cervical cancer screening participation and knowledge level. Results Among 1504 participants, 31.3 % ever attended cervical cancer screening. In the recommended age group of 25–64 years, the participation rate was 35.2 %. Screening participation was associated with age, marital status, occupation, and history of genital tract infection. Approximately 20.9 % had heard of human papillomavirus, 23.2 % knew cervical cancer is preventable, and 41.6 % had heard of cervical cancer screening. Awareness of risk factors, screening techniques, and symptoms was limited. The median knowledge score was 2.0 out of 19.0. Knowledge level was associated with education, age at menarche, number of sexual partners, and history of genital tract infection. Most (99.7 %) participants were willing to attend cervical cancer screening, but only 84.5 % would accept therapy if necessary. The most common barrier to therapy was unaffordable cost. Conclusions Migrant Burmese women in Mangshi had suboptimal screening participation and inadequate cervical cancer knowledge. Screening policies should prioritize socioeconomically disadvantaged women. Enhancing targeted health education is essential. Highlights • Migrant Burmese women in China had limited cervical cancer screening participation and knowledge. • Screening policies should prioritize socioeconomically marginalized Burmese women. • Tailored health education addressing linguistic and cultural barriers is vital. Keywords Cervical cancer Cervical cancer screening Immigrant Burmese Practice Knowledge Attitude pmc-status-qastatus 0 pmc-status-live yes pmc-status-embargo no pmc-status-released yes pmc-prop-open-access yes pmc-prop-olf no pmc-prop-manuscript no pmc-prop-legally-suppressed no pmc-prop-has-pdf yes pmc-prop-has-supplement no pmc-prop-pdf-only no pmc-prop-suppress-copyright no pmc-prop-is-real-version no pmc-prop-is-scanned-article no pmc-prop-preprint no pmc-prop-in-epmc yes 1 Introduction Cervical cancer is the fourth common cancer among women globally, with an estimated 662,301 new cases and 348,874 deaths in 2022, disproportionately affecting low- and middle-income countries ( Bray et al., 2024 Li et al., 2017 Sun et al., 2024 Correspondingly, the World Health Organization and China's National Health Commission have launched initiatives to eliminate cervical cancer through expanded population-based screening. According to the Guidelines for Cervical Cancer Screening in China Li et al., 2023 Action Plan to Accelerate the Elimination of Cervical Cancer (2023–2030) Simms et al., 2019 Zhao et al., 2023 Bao et al., 2018 Bruni et al., 2022 Bucchi et al., 2019 Rosato et al., 2023 Crawford et al., 2016 Marques et al., 2020 Mangshi, a multiethnic border county in Dehong prefecture, Southwest China's Yunnan province, with a population of 464.3 thousand, hosts a large number of Burmese migrants who are at increased risk of sexually transmitted infections (STIs). Human immunodeficiency virus prevalence among migrant Burmese in cross-border marriages in Dehong prefecture and its capital Mangshi county has reached 2.0 % ( Xu et al., 2022 Yang et al., 2021 Gong et al., 2019 Han et al., 2016 2 Methods 2.1 Study design and participants This cross-sectional study was conducted at Mangshi Maternal and Child Health Hospital between October 2020 and December 2021. The hospital is the only facility that undertakes population-based cervical and breast cancer screening in the county. The Cervical and Breast Cancer Screening Clinic of this hospital offers free routine gynecological examinations to women with a history of sexual activity. All women attending routine gynecological examinations at the screening clinic were eligible if they: 1) were aged 14–70 years; 2) had initiated sexual intercourse; 3) had an intact cervix; 4) had no history of cervical treatment and pelvic radiotherapy; 5) were not currently pregnant; 6) were born in Myanmar with Burmese nationality; and 8) could understand the objectives, procedures, potential risks, and expected benefits of the study, and volunteered to attend the study. 2.2 Sample size determination and sampling Sample size was determined using the single-population proportion formula: (1) n = Z 1 − α / 2 2 p 1 − p / d 2 Assuming a 25.7 % expected screening coverage ( Zhang et al., 2020 2.3 Instrument and variables 2.3.1 Questionnaire The questionnaire used for interview was developed by a multidisciplinary team of gynecologists and epidemiologists and applied in several previous studies on knowledge, attitudes, and practices regarding cervical cancer ( He et al., 2017 Zhang et al., 2018a Zhang et al., 2018b Zhao et al., 2022 2.3.2 Outcome variables The primary outcome was cervical cancer screening participation, which was defined if a participant had ever attended cervical cancer screening. The secondary outcome was knowledge level. In this domain, single-choice questions were scored as one for “yes” and zero for “no” or “unknown”; multiple-choice questions awarded one point per correct answer, with a maximum score of 19 points. Knowledge level was dichotomized into high (>2 points) and low (≤2 points) levels based on the median knowledge score (2 points), following the method adopted in previous studies ( Hu et al., 2021 Xu et al., 2021 2.3.3 Explanatory variables Included variables and categorizations are as follows: age (14–24, 25–29, 30–34, 35–39, 40–44, 45–49, 50–63), marital status (single, married/cohabitating, divorced/widowed/separated), education (no formal education, primary, secondary or higher), occupational status (housewife/unemployed, farmer/laborer, public institution/company), age at menache (<14, ≥14), age at sexual debut (<20, ≥20), number of sexual partners in the last three years (≤1, >1, refuse to answer), number of deliveries (0, 1, 2, ≥3), and history of genital tract infection (GTI) (yes, no). 2.3.4 Other descriptive variables In the knowledge domain, participants who had heard of cervical cancer screening were asked about the information source. In attitudes domain, participants were asked about the willingness to participate in cervical cancer screening and perceived facilitators for participation. Regarding attitudes toward therapy, participants were asked whether they would be willing to receive therapy in a hypothetical situation where treatment would be required following screening or diagnostic results indicating precancerous lesions or cervical cancer. Participants unwilling to receive therapy even if necessary were asked about perceived barriers. 2.4 Interview and data collection All participants were interviewed face-to-face and one-on-one by trained health workers using the questionnaire in appropriate settings to ensure privacy, either at the clinic, participants' homes, or community centers in their villages, depending on participants' availability and scheduling considerations. Necessary prevention measures were implemented throughout the survey, including mask wearing, body temperature check, physical distancing, and hand disinfection, in light of the public health situation during the Covid-19 pandemic. Data were entered by trained health workers via the Goodata system, which allowed safe storage of data, data export, logic checks, and outlier and discrepancy alerts. Personal identifiers were removed from the database used for analysis to ensure participants' confidentiality. The data were stored securely in password-protected files, and access to data was limited to the core research team. 2.5 Statistical analysis Participants' characteristics were reported using frequencies with percentages. Univariable and multivariable binary logistic regressions were applied to identify factors associated with cervical cancer screening participation and knowledge level. Variables with p p 2.6 Ethics Ethical approval was obtained from the Ethics Committee of the National Cancer Center/Cancer Hospital, Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences and Peking Union Medical College, Beijing, China (Approval Number: 18-190/1768). All participants, as well as the parents/guardians of minors under the age of 18, were fully informed of the objectives, procedures, potential risks, and expected benefits, and voluntarily participated in the study. Written informed consent was obtained from all adult participants. Both written informed consent from parents/guardians and written assent from participants were obtained for minors under the age of 18. For participants who were illiteracy, fingerprint was used instead of signature for informed consent. Participants had the right to leave the study at any time. All methods were performed following relevant guidelines and regulations, and participants' privacy, confidentiality, and rights were consistently protected throughout the study. 3 Results 3.1 Sociodemographic characteristics A total of 1504 out of 1588 Burmese women with valid responses were included in the final analysis. The age of participants ranged between 14 and 63 years. The majority (88.1 %) were married or cohabitating. Approximately 40.2 % had no formal education, and 68.3 % worked as farmers or laborers. Over half experienced menarche at age 14 or later (56.7 %) and first intercourse at age 20 or later (60.0 %). Most (90.5 %) reported no more than one sexual partner in the last three years. Approximately one-fifth had heard of human papillomavirus (HPV) (20.9 %) or knew cervical cancer is preventable (23.2 %). HPV infection (12.2 %) and multiple sexual partners (12.0 %) were the most frequently identified risk factors. A total of 626 (41.6 %) participants had heard of cervical cancer screening, mainly through health professionals (91.4 %) ( Fig. 1 Table 3 Fig. 1 Information sources of cervical cancer screening for Burmese women in Mangshi, China (2020–2021) (multiple choices). Health education (93.1 %) and well-organization (66.0 %) were the most frequently mentioned facilitators. Unaffordable cost (84.5 %) was the predominantly mentioned barrier among those who were unwilling to receive therapy even if necessary ( Table 5 Table 5 Attitudes toward cervical cancer screening and therapy among Burmese women in Mangshi, China, 2020–2021 (n = 1504). Table 5 Characteristics N % Willingness to participate in cervical cancer screening 1500 99.7 Perceived facilitators to participating in cervical cancer screening a Health education 1397 93.1 Well-organized programs 990 66.0 Providing transportation subsidies 489 32.6 Persuasion from family members or friends 480 32.0 Option of self-sampling method 115 7.7 Willingness to receive therapy if necessary 1271 84.5 Perceived barriers to receiving therapy b Unaffordable cost of therapy 197 84.5 A far distance from hospitals 17 7.3 Presenting no symptoms 11 4.7 Time constraint 6 2.6 Other 2 0.9 a Participants who were willing to attend cervical cancer screening ( n b Participants who were unwilling to receive therapy even if necessary ( n 4 Discussion This study revealed low cervical cancer screening participation and limited cervical cancer knowledge among migrant Burmese women in Mangshi, China. Although most expressed willingness to attend screening, approximately 15 % were unwilling to receive therapy even if necessary, primarily due to unaffordable cost. Approximately 35.2 % of Burmese women in recommended age group in our study had attended cervical cancer screening, notably lower than that of native Chinese in the capital city of Yunnan province (58.1 %) ( Yuanyue et al., 2018 Rosato et al., 2023 Al-Oseely et al., 2023 Chigbu et al., 2013 Hertzum-Larsen et al., 2019 Al-Oseely et al., 2023 Currently, however, there is no specific national cervical cancer screening policies/programs in China for migrant populations. In many regions, access to free screening services is restricted by quotas, household registration, or place of residence, which limits the inclusion of migrant women. Some border areas in Yunnan province have made specific provisions to include Burmese women in free screening programs. However, in many of these cases, eligibility is limited to those with legal residency and a formal marital relationship with Chinese citizen; Mangshi only lifted these restrictions in 2025. Similarly in Guangxi province, the border town Naliang has extended free screening services to Vietnamese women, but still restricts eligibility to those registered as local residents or permanent inhabitants. These underscore urgent need to address structural barriers in policies to improve access to cervical cancer screening among migrant women in recommended screening age group, especially those without legal citizenship and socioeconomically disadvantaged ( Guerrero et al., 2016 High knowledge level is also associated with cervical cancer screening participation among migrant women ( Al-Oseely et al., 2023 Mon et al., 2009 Wint, 2019 Yuanyue et al., 2018 Bhattacharya et al., 2022 Ekechi et al., 2014 Riza et al., 2020 Migrant Burmese women in our study demonstrated poorer knowledge of cervical cancer etiology, risk factors, and symptoms compared to both native Chinese women in the same province and native Burmese women ( Mon et al., 2009 Yuanyue et al., 2018 Uysal Toraman and Yildirim, 2018 Azzani et al., 2023 Women with vulnerable characteristics should be prioritized in health education. In our study, higher education and earlier menarche were associated with better knowledge, and history of GTI was associated with both better knowledge and screening participation, consistent with previous findings ( Argaw et al., 2022 Issa et al., 2021 Muluneh et al., 2019 Zhang et al., 2023 Peruga et al., 1993 Zhang et al., 2023 In the attitude domain, good organization was another critical facilitator mentioned by Burmese women. As most lacked access to workplace-based health check-ups, this strategy in urban areas is unfeasible in remote low-resource areas. Instead, community- or village-based screening programs should be considered. HPV-testing, with its lower frequency requirements and self-sampling option, may also enhance participation among hard-to-reach women ( Alam et al., 2023 Arrossi et al., 2015 Our study shows fewer women were willing to receive therapy than to undergo screening, with unaffordable cost being the most vital barrier. This phenomenon may be attributed to the limitations in financial support policies. In China, public financial assistance schemes for cervical/breast cancer therapy targeting women with low-income are subject to local household registration in most regions, including border areas like Mangshi. Even those maintaining a legal marriage with a Chinese citizen, who may have access to free screening programs, may be excluded from assistance schemes for cancer therapy. This emphasizes the need for robust follow-up and referral systems and inclusive financial support to address health inequity in low-resource border areas. To our knowledge, this is the first study assessing cervical cancer screening participation, knowledge, and attitudes among migrant women in China. The findings could provide insights for tailoring screening strategies and health education for migrant women in remote areas with limited health resources. However, several limitations should be noted. First, it was a monocenter study without probability sampling, though a sample size larger than anticipation might partly offset selection bias. Therefore, conclusions are limited to Burmese women in Mangshi county, and generalization to other migrant populations in border areas should be made with caution. Second, the cross-sectional design made it impossible to establish causal relationships between independent factors and outcomes. Third, recall and reporting biases inevitably existed in self-reported data. Fourth, critical factors including residency status were not fully collected. 5 Conclusions In summary, migrant Burmese women in China's southwest border areas had insufficient screening participation and inadequate knowledge regarding cervical cancer. Screening policies and financial support should prioritize socioeconomically marginalized migrant women in recommended age group. Structural barriers, such as limitations on household registration, residency status, and marital relationship, should be reduced to promote health equity. Targeted health education is essential, particularly for those who have low education, experience menarche at an older age, refuse to report sexual history, and have no GTI history. Linguistic and cultural barriers should be addressed. Screening programs should adapt to migrants' living conditions.
